goals.question: What is the distribution of movie ratings?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of movie ratings and identify any outliers.

goals.question: What is the relationship between movie budget and revenue?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify any correlation between movie budget and revenue, and determine if higher budgets lead to higher revenues.

goals.question: What is the most common genre of movies in the dataset?
goals.visualization: Bar chart of the count of each genre in the 'genres' field
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us identify the most popular genre of movies in the dataset and potentially inform future movie production decisions.

goals.question: What is the distribution of movie runtimes?
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the spread of movie runtimes and identify any outliers.

goals.question: What is the distribution of movie release years?
goals.visualization: Line chart of the count of movies released per year
goals.rationale: This visualization will help us understand the trend of movie releases over time and potentially inform future movie production decisions.

code:
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    sns.histplot(data=data, x='rating', kde=True, color='blue')
    plt.axvline(data['rating'].mean(), color='red', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label=f"Mean: {data['rating'].mean():.2f}")
    plt.axvline(data['rating'].median(), color='green', linestyle='dashed', linewidth=1, label=f"Median: {data['rating'].median():.2f}")
    plt.legend()
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['budget'] = pd.to_numeric(data['budget'], errors='coerce')
    data['revenue'] = pd.to_numeric(data['revenue'], errors='coerce')
    chart = sns.scatterplot(x='budget', y='revenue', data=data)
    plt.title('What is the relationship between movie budget and revenue?', wrap=True)
    return chart

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['genres'] = data['genres'].apply(lambda x: x.split(',')[0])
    genre_count = data['genres'].value_counts()
    plt.figure(figsize=(10,5))
    sns.barplot(x=genre_count.index, y=genre_count.values, palette='Blues_d')
    plt.title('What is the most common genre of movies in the dataset?', wrap=True)
    plt.xlabel('Genre')
    plt.ylabel('Count')
    plt.xticks(rotation=45)
    for i, v in enumerate(genre_count.values):
        plt.text(i, v, str(v), ha='center', va='bottom', fontweight='bold')
    return plt;

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['runtime'] = pd.to_numeric(data['runtime'], errors='coerce')
    sns.histplot(data=data, x='runtime', kde=True, color='blue')
    plt.axvline(data['runtime'].median(), color='red', label=f'Median: {data["runtime"].median():.2f}')
    plt.legend()
    plt.title('What is the distribution of movie runtimes?', wrap=True)
    return plt

chart = plot(data)

import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

def plot(data: pd.DataFrame):
    data['release_year'] = pd.to_datetime(data['release_date'], format='%Y-%m-%d', errors='coerce').dt.year
    data = data.dropna(subset=['release_year'])
    data = data.groupby('release_year').size().reset_index(name='count')
    chart = sns.lineplot(x='release_year', y='count', data=data)
    chart.set(xlabel='Release Year', ylabel='Count')
    plt.title('What is the distribution of movie release years?', wrap=True)
    return plt

chart = plot(data)
